course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Quantum Information for Everyone
course.description: Information cannot exist without a physical system to represent it. Quantum physics enables some fundamental new ways of information processing. In recent years, quantum information processing (QIP) has emerged as one of the “most fiercely competitive in today’s world of technology”. This course offers an introduction to the past, present and future of QIP. The theme is to explain the major ideas and issues in QIP, and how this new technology will change our understanding of information processing. The course starts from a gentle introduction to quantum theory without assuming any physics background, then moves to the key applications of QIP including quantum computing, quantum cryptography, and quantum communication. Besides theory, demonstrations and hands-on experiences with quantum hardware will also be given. Students will benefit from learning quantum information technology in an interdisciplinary environment, with knowledge and skills for comprehending the fast-paced developments in today’s technological world.
course.prerequisites: Level 3 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M2

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Only take it if you got backgrounds.
reviews.comment_content:
Some said the contents are too abstract and aren’t practical enough... well, I agree... but... how would you expect the content be practical when there are still many years before we will be using a quantum computer to join the zoom.

Topics are: Complex Numbers, Quantum Wavefunction, Computer Organization, Quantum Computer Architecture, Quantum Algorithms, Quantum Cryptography, Information Theory, Quantum Error Correction.
I would hope if Quantum Software and Quantum Hardware (they are chapters from the textbook) can be included as well.

Each of the slides are prepared with a quantum version plus a traditional counterparts, trying to show us how “far” the quantum world can give us. Which is good to let is know more about the differences between traditional and the quantum.

However, I gave a B to the contents mainly because of the pre-requisites. WARNING: take this course ONLY if you have taken MATH2111/2121. Best if you are major in Physics with PHYS2022 taken, or if you are major in CS with COMP2611 taken.

With M2 as the pre-requisite, umm..., you will be quite confused with all the things taught. The workload for you to grasp an understanding about the contents from zero background is definitely huge.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I don’t know how to say. I can feel the Prof teaches with heart, and she is also responsive to students. When we asked her to post hand-written notes, she did post. Also, she is willing to answer students questions during class.

However, I personally don’t like her teaching style. She jumps from pages to another, which is hard to follow. She is definitely not the person that can teach students from “zero”. Which means, if you come into the class with background, it would probably be okay; but if you come with blank, you may be really confused with her teaching. Her accent was not too good to comprehend as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Can’t say it is very bad, but I don’t think it is good either.

Scheme:
5% participation
15% weekly canvas quiz (homework)
35% midterm exam
45% final exam

What I got:
Total 83.875 with overall mean around 73.
I got 13/20 in midterm with mean 13.1 (I will explain more below)
I got 27/30 in final with mean 21.6
Full in homework + attendance 20/20 with mean around 19-19.5 I guess.

Grade: B+
P.S. I have sent an email asking the TA. Cutoff between B+ and A- is 85 (which means one single more question correct in either midterm or final.... cry!!)
Should be 5 points a sub-grade, 85-90 A-, 90-95 A...

However, I gave C in this criteria for the following two reasons:
1. The midterm exam sucks. It is the go-ahead-no-return type canvas quiz. However, some question involves tedious calculation, there is a question asking for the inner product of tensor products of 2x1 matrices with each entry being complex. (Complex numbers mean you need to do the multiplication two times, so you need to do 16 multiplications before having the tensor product on one side; another 16 the another side, then you do another 16 multiplication between the two tensor products and you also need to do 15 additions on both real and complex parts for simplifying. There are 63 steps before you reach an answer.... lol, correct me if I am wrong). Since the exams are open book open internet, students can use any codings to perform the matrix computation. Many used octave; however, I did not know how to use it... I spent quite a lot of time struggling for that question. But I don’t know whether I should skip it or not since I couldn’t come back to check for that question later even I got time left. The midterm exam consists of way too many computational question, which was also the reason for me not performing well on the midterm. I think the mode of assessment did not really comply with the objectives of this course. Isn’t this course “quantum information”?? I thought it was “Coding for Computations” :(

2. The grading curve isn’t good neither. I was upset that given many technical difficulties and mistakes in many exams and homeworks, plus this course is brand new that many students did not know the contents in advance when taking it, plus also it is a common core with unreasonable pre-requisites, it is still giving shitty grade. Well, not shitty, but average gradings. It isn’t giving exceptionally better grades; however, it should, given all these.

Since HKUST typically says mean is C, I will give the “grading” C here. I think the grading scheme and the distribution, as well as the assessment modes are not really good enough. They are not very worse, but average.

Rooms for improvements:
1. Allow all-in final
2. Don’t include computation questions too much
3. Don’t do one-way forward quiz.
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy workload. I am thinking even you do not attend class but somehow showed up a bit, you got full in parti.

Homeworks are not difficult, you will immediately know your results as they are just Canvas quizzes. You got three attempts where most students got full here.

Midterm and Final are intensive given limited time, but tbh the questions are not that difficult if you got time. You have nothing to do in revising for the exams except for the sample paper. I would recommend you go play around with Octave or Matlab before taking the exams. They may even be more useful than practicing with the sample paper.

reviews.author: Qwerty233

reviews.author: OsamaBinLaden69
reviews.comment_content: The course was supposed to be an introductory one, but I think it should be recommended for people who have a little background in this or pitched as a higher level course rather than an introductory common core course. Regardless, if you like this sort of stuff you might find the contents pretty interesting. There was a big focus on quantum gates and how quibits would interact with a quantum circuit. Other topics included: Vector and matrix stuff (eigenstuff,  hermitian and unitary matrices, tensor product etc), Quantum states, probability, Bits and Quibits, Q gates, various algorithms(Deutsch–Jozsa, Simons, Grovers, etc), cryptography and information theory. The textbook for reference was Quantum computing for computer scientists (Noson S. Yanofsky, Micro A. Manucci), however I did not end up using it that much and instead used the lecture notes, which were also not that great. So I would say that the provided resources could be much better.
reviews.comment_teaching: It was alright. I think it could have been better, but she did put in the effort.
reviews.comment_grading: I thought that the grading was pretty tough, maybe because the course attracts people who are already interested in this sort of stuff? I had to guess a lot of the questions, but from my experience, many others were in the same boat. The midterm was also a lot easier than the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Quizes every week that you can attempt 3 times, and the questions were pretty similar to the actual exam questions.

reviews.author: Plusle
reviews.title: 冇人講咪我講囉
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
Complex numbers and vectors, Basic quantum theory, Quantum probability, Quantum bits and quantum gates, Quantum entanglement, Quantum circuits, Quantum algorithm, Quantum cryptography, Quantum error correction

Textbook:
Yanofsky and Mannucci, “Quantum Computing for Computer Scientists”, Cambridge University Press, 2008

The content is interesting, and might be useful if you work in computer science (it is essentially a COMP course). Famous quantum algorithms are explained in details (except for Shor’s algorithm, when I think it should be the climax of this course, it was introduced just very briefly), and they might be very useful in the future(?)

Mathematics prerequisite includes complex number and linear algebra. Basically all maths needed would be introduced in the first two weeks. Overall the problems are not very difficult and everything in homework and exams can be done with the help of MATLAB / Octave. But it is still good if you have a basic understanding in the maths before you take this course (e.g. complex number in polar form, vector basis and linear dependence, eigenvectors and eigenvalues). Year 1 BB like me may have to take a look at these concepts first.

The textbook is not particularly good, as it sometimes uses some very weird conventions that make readers confused. But the good point is that it explains its examples with detailed steps and it is rather easy to follow. If you don’t like to read, just follow the lectures and homework questions would be enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Bei ZENG

As Zeng said, this course is example-oriented, and everything will be illustrated by examples. She explained those examples quite clearly, and it should not be difficult to follow her and finish the homework. But as a matter of fact, concepts in quantum physics are difficult to truly understand, so sometimes you may just be able to do all the maths, but you don’t know what is actually happening. (Famous quote of David Mermin, “Shut up and calculate.”)

Zeng also tried hard to be interactive in lessons, which made the lesson a bit more interesting. (Though not very successful in online/mixed mode).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading system:
Class participation: 5%
Assignments: 15%
Mid-term test: 35%
Final exam: 45%

Zeng had once said there should be no problems for class participation if you attend more than half of the lectures (I personally skipped around 5 to 6 lectures, but I don’t know the final outcome for this.).

For assignment, there were 10 in total, each with 10 questions (max 3 attempts). It was not very difficult, so the mean scores were usually very high. Try your best to get full score. Make sure you have saved your attempts (screen-capturing or printing-to-PDF) before you submit, so that you can revisit your answers if your score is not full.

For mid-term and final, there were both MCs and numeric questions. They were more difficult than homework problems. The difficulty was increased by adding more qubits to the circuit, setting some variables instead of numbers in questions, etc. But overall the style was somewhat similar to homework problems. For online exam mode, please get used to Octave before you take the exam, as it can speed up your calculation a lot. Dealing with the matrix multiplication by hand can be troublesome.

Eventually I got an A+. Some said that a mean score gives a B. (Not sure though, plus this is a completely new course, thus grading standards might be subject to changes in the future.)

Data:
Class participation: unknown
Assignments: full
Mid-term test: 18 / 20   (Mean = 13.1)
Final exam: 28 / 30   (Mean = 21.3)

Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light. Weekly assignments take around 1 hour to finish. Usually it is not very hard, but sometimes it is frustrating if you get one or two questions wrong but you can’t figure out where the mistakes are.

For revision just go through all homework and one practice paper would be enough.

reviews.author: wbs77
reviews.title: do not take without prior knowledge in CS
reviews.comment_content:
Weekly schedule:

Week 1: A brief history of computers
Week 2: A brief introduction to quantum computers
Week 3: Matrix representation of quantum gates
Week 4: Quantum circuits, search algorithm
       Quiz 1 on Mar 1

Week 5: Complex numbers, single qubit gates
Week 6: Universal circuits, quantum Fourier transform
Week 7: Quantum mechanics, quantum entanglement
       Quiz 2 on Mar 21

Week 8: A brief introduction to building quantum computers
Week 9: Breaking RSA encryption
Week 10: A brief introduction to quantum cryptography
         Quiz 3 on April 12

Week 11: A brief introduction to quantum communication
Week 12: A brief introduction to quantum error correction
         Quiz 4 on May 3

Week 13: Hands on experiments with quantum computer*
*Experiments will be scheduled in April and May, in small groups.
(taken directly from the teachers canvas)

In my opinion there was too much content and the pace was very fast. As a student with no prior knowledge in the subject I was very much behind a lot of people considering its an intro course. Most people were from CS so they had a lot of knowledge on gates and such so they were way faster than I was and since most quizzes were very short in time I had to guess half of the quiz while other students probably did way faster.
The lab report was fine tho not that hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say the teaching wasn't really in the way I could understand. The teacher went over some subjects as though we had learned it before and it made me feel very left behind since I hadn't learned it before. The slides that she has are very messy and don't really include a lot of detail, mostly graphs and diagrams, not much content so you really have to listen in class and take notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
I guess grading was fair. Considering I didn't know anything before the course, I still don't know anything which I guess id judtified by my grade. Not very surprised but as definitely a disadvantage since I was competing against people who already knew most of the stuff.
5% by course participation
10% by quantum computer experimental report
40% by four in-class quiz (10% per quiz)
45% by final exam
reviews.comment_workload: Just 4 in class quizess, a final exam and a lab report. No homework, nothing else really.

reviews.author: 君隐甲辰
reviews.title: REALLY WORTH A TRY!
reviews.comment_content: The course has been simplified compared to last year and has become a true "for everyone" course in Quantum Information. Also I think it contains a good introduction to modern computer architecture as well. But I do agree that this may be a little difficult for year 1 students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This was probably my favourite course of my enrolment, for me the pace of the teacher and the style of the lesson was perfect.  I admit that I was influenced by last year's reviews before the course started, but all my concerns were put to rest once the course actually started.
So if you still need a class now, I hope you won't regret taking this one!
reviews.comment_grading: The teacher also mentioned this, saying that the exam would be streamlined and the distribution of grades would be optimised in line with last year's situation.
reviews.comment_workload: As a year 4 exchange student, I would think that if you are interested in the subject, at least the first half of this course will not be a burden. I don't know how the sections on quantum algorithms and such will be as the professor hasn't uploaded the files yet, but as she has mentioned many times that she has gained a lot of experience from her first start, I think the workload for this course will at least be reasonable.
